options.text: To develop a new treatment for syphilis.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of syphilis cases in the United States.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the study, and how many men were left alive when it ended?

options.label: A
options.text: The study showed that syphilis did not have any long-term effects, and 600 men were left alive.

options.label: B
options.text: The study showed that syphilis had long-term effects, and 74 men were left alive.

options.label: C
options.text: The study showed that syphilis did not have any racial differences, and 74 men were left alive.

options.label: D
options.text: The study showed that syphilis had long-term effects, and 600 men were left alive.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why you should stop setting goals (yes, really) - Emmanuel Acho

options.text: Because they want to be famous.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they've been indoctrinated with the belief that setting goals is necessary for success.

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: Why is it so hard to break a bad habit?

multiple-choice.question: What is a habit, according to scientists?

options.label: A
options.text: A behavior that is performed regularly and cued subconsciously in response to certain environments.

options.label: B
options.text: A behavior that is performed regularly and cued consciously in response to certain environments.

options.label: C
options.text: A behavior that is performed occasionally and cued subconsciously in response to certain environments.

options.label: D
options.text: A behavior that is performed occasionally and cued consciously in response to certain environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of dopamine in the formation of habits?

options.label: A
options.text: Dopamine suppresses feelings of pleasure and motivates the release of dopamine.

options.label: B
options.text: Dopamine mediates feelings of pleasure and drives neuroplasticity.

options.label: C
options.text: Dopamine has no role in the formation of habits.

options.label: D
options.text: Dopamine is released only when a habit is broken.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why habits are difficult to break?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are ingrained in our daily routines.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are cued by environments and routines.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are triggered by emotions and stress.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not beneficial to us.

multiple-choice.question: What is one effective way to manage behavior and break a habit?

options.label: A
options.text: By identifying and changing the environment or routine that triggers the habit.

options.label: B
options.text: By using willpower to resist the habit.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the habit and hoping it goes away.

options.label: D
options.text: By replacing the habit with a new one.

multiple-choice.question: What is habit reversal training, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: Habit reversal training is a technique that helps to identify and change the cues that trigger a habit. Its purpose is to replace the habit with a new one.

options.label: B
options.text: Habit reversal training is a technique that helps to identify and change the environment that triggers a habit. Its purpose is to break the habit.

options.label: C
options.text: Habit reversal training is a technique that helps to ignore the habit and hope it goes away. Its purpose is to reduce stress and anxiety.

options.label: D
options.text: Habit reversal training is a technique that has no purpose.

multiple-choice.question: What is one benefit of understanding the basis of habits?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to break habits easily and quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us to identify and change the cues that trigger habits.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us to manage behavior and make positive changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is one study that demonstrated the effectiveness of changing environments in breaking habits?

options.label: A
options.text: A study that tracked university students' exercising, reading, and TV watching habits before and after they transferred schools.

options.label: B
options.text: A study that tracked people's eating habits before and after they changed their diet.

options.label: C
options.text: A study that studied the effects of exercise on mental health.

options.label: D
options.text: A study that had no relevance to habits.

multiple-choice.question: What is one benefit of habits?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always detrimental to us.

options.label: B
options.text: They are never beneficial to us.

options.label: C
options.text: They are stored memories of what's worked in the past, which allow us to take swift action in the present.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to break a habit?

options.label: A
options.text: By ignoring the habit and hoping it goes away.

options.label: B
options.text: By using willpower to resist the habit.

options.label: C
options.text: By replacing the habit with a new one.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Habits are always bad and should be avoided.

options.label: B
options.text: Habits are always good and should be encouraged.

options.label: C
options.text: Habits are a normal part of life and can be managed and changed.

options.label: D
options.text: Habits have no relevance to our lives.

title: The psychology of post-traumatic stress disorder - Joelle Maletis

multiple-choice.question: What is post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)?

options.label: A
options.text: A mental illness that causes people to become more outgoing and confident.

options.label: B
options.text: A treatable malfunction of certain biological mechanisms that allow us to cope with dangerous experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: A physical condition that can be cured with medication.

options.label: D
options.text: A personality disorder that affects people's relationships.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "fight-flight-freeze" response?

options.label: A
options.text: A response to danger that involves running away.

options.label: B
options.text: A response to danger that involves fighting back.

options.label: C
options.text: A response to danger that involves freezing inaction or paralysis.

options.label: D
options.text: A response to danger that involves seeking help.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when the "fight-flight-freeze" response is activated?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart rate slows down, breathing quickens, and muscles relax.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart rate speeds up, breathing quickens, and muscles tense.

options.label: C
options.text: The body becomes numb and unresponsive.

options.label: D
options.text: The body becomes calm and relaxed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the HPA axis?

options.label: A
options.text: A network of nerves that regulates the autonomic nervous system.

options.label: B
options.text: A system of glands that produces stress hormones.

options.label: C
options.text: A network of glands that regulates digestion and respiration.

options.label: D
options.text: A system of nerves that regulates heart rate and blood pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What is cortisol?

options.label: A
options.text: A hormone that helps regulate the "fight-flight-freeze" response.

options.label: B
options.text: A hormone that helps regulate digestion and respiration.

options.label: C
options.text: A hormone that helps regulate heart rate and blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: A hormone that helps regulate stress and anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What are the four categories of symptoms associated with PTSD?

options.label: A
options.text: Intrusive thoughts, avoiding reminders of the trauma, negative thoughts and feelings, and "reactive" symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Intrusive thoughts, negative thoughts and feelings, and "reactive" symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding reminders of the trauma, negative thoughts and feelings, and "reactive" symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: Intrusive thoughts, avoiding reminders of the trauma, and "reactive" symptoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is a trigger?

options.label: A
options.text: A stimulus that causes a person to experience PTSD symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: A stimulus that causes a person to feel calm and relaxed.

options.label: C
options.text: A stimulus that causes a person to become more outgoing and confident.

options.label: D
options.text: A stimulus that causes a person to become less anxious and stressed.

multiple-choice.question: What can people with PTSD do to manage their symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Seek evaluation and treatment from a mental health professional.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid triggers and try to relax.

options.label: C
options.text: Try to forget about their trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: Try to become more outgoing and confident.

multiple-choice.question: What is social support?

options.label: A
options.text: The support of friends and family members.

options.label: B
options.text: The support of a mental health professional.

options.label: D
options.text: The support of a support group.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for PTSD being called?
